Re: License #: CB820201485
Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
1/4/2024. An exit conference was held with your agency on 1/8/2024 Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing on the CWL-4617 Acknowledgement
of appeal rights. If you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must notify this
office in writing and an administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even if you contest the
issuance of a provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable corrective action
plan.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
2 of 17 new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of an out of
state children protective services clearance for the employee who had lived out of
state in South Carolina and Texas respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
It is noteworthy the agency completes a 90-day probationary performance
evaluation for new employees to satisfy one aspect of this rule.
2

8 of 26 employee records reviewed did not show compliance to the rule:
• One record showed, per the employee’s 11/14/2023 date of hire, that the
employee’s probationary performance evaluation was due by 2/14/2023; and
was completed on 10/17/2023.
• A second record did not show documentation of the employee’s probationary
performance evaluation due by 4/30/2023 and 9/12/2023 respectively.
• A third and fourth record showed the employee’s probationary performance
evaluation due by 3/5/2023 and 5/13/2023 were completed late on 4/28/2023
and 7/24/2023 respectively.
• A fifth and sixth record did not show documentation of the employee’s annual
performance evaluation which were due by 4/15/2023 and 5/13/2023
respectively.
• A seventh record showed the employee’s annual performance evaluation due
by 4/14/2023 was completed late on 5/11/2023.
• An eighth record showed the employee’s annual performance evaluation due
by 4/15/2023 was not documented.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2021 Interim
inspection with the corrective plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request.
(3) An agency shall provide the licensee an application
for renewal of the license and document the action not
less than 60 calendar days before the expiration date of
the license. A renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending recommendation for
disciplinary action of the license.
1 of 7 open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation that an
application was provided at least 60 days prior to the foster home's 5/3/2023.
license expiration date.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2021 Interim inspection with the corrective
plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster
home license.
3

1 of 7 open foster home records reviewed showed the revaluation was not
submitted at least 15 days prior to the foster home’s 5/3/2023 license expiration
date.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2021 Interim
inspection with the corrective plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following:
(a) Approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of a child in the home.
1 of 1 borrowed home records reviewed showed the agency's authorization from the
certificating agency for the placement was after the 10/2/2023 borrowed home date.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within
45 calendar days after receipt of the information. If
additional time is required, then the agency shall inform
the foster parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension
and the expected length of the extension. The total time
for the completion of the investigation may not exceed 90
calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
1 of 3 special evaluations reviewed showed the 45-day letter due by 7/21/2023 was
completed late on 9/8/2023. Additionally, the evaluation exceeded 90-days and the
record did not show documentation of an approval from the chief administrator or his
or her designee.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
4

In 2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed, where there was a change of
placement for one child; and three replacements for the other child, the respective
record did not show documentation of (g) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
In 6 of 8 closed foster child records reviewed, the record did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2021 Interim inspection, with the corrective
plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
2 of 8 open foster home records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child's 14-month annual medical exam was due by
10/3/2023 and completed late on 11/1/2023.
• A second record showed the child’s 14-month annual medical exam was due
by 4/11/2023 and completed late on 5/9/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed showed the child's dental reexamination
was due by 7/19/2023 and was completed almost two months late on 9/12/2023.
5

Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2021 Interim inspection, with the corrective
plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 2 initial service plans (ISP) reviewed was 6 days late.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2021 Interim
inspection with the corrective plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
6 of 29 updated service plans (USP) reviewed (related to 3 or 8 foster child records
reviewed did not show compliance:
• 2 were 1 day late:
• 1 was 7 days late.
• 1 was 11 days late.
• 1 was 14 days late.
• It is noted there was a gap in service plans for one youth. An updated service
plan was completed covering 2/28/2023-5/24/2023 then the next covered
7/12/2023-8/17/2023. The period of 5/25/2023-7/11/2023 was not covered.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2021 Interim
inspection with the corrective plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be used
by the foster parents.
6

6 of 29 updated service plans reviewed (related to 2 of 8 open foster child records
reviewed) did not show documentation of the specific behavior support plan to be
used by the caregiver.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
In 1 of 8 open foster child record reviewed the record did not show documentation of
a March 2023 visit with the child and caregiver in the child's placement.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in independent
living.
3 of 6 open independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
that a copy of the program statement was provided to the youth prior to the date of
placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency's policies and procedures
required by this rule.
3 of 6 open independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
that a copy of the program's policies and procedures were provided to the youth
prior to the date of placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023.
7

CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth's place of residence.
1 of 6 open independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of a May and June 2023 visit at the youth's placement/current location. Office visits
occurred with the youth.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(e) An evaluation of a youth's need for supervision and a
plan for providing the level of supervision determined
necessary.
2 of 6 open independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of an initial assessment of the youth's need for supervision, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient
to meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and
miscellaneous expenses.
1 of 6 open independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of proof of a May or August budget/proof of financial support to meet the youth's
needs, after the initial one on 2/21/2023, as required by the rule.
8

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate.
2 of 14 independent living service plans reviewed (related to 2 of 6 open
independent youth records reviewed) were late by 3 and 13 days respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(1) There must be a mutual agreement between the
youth and the agency specifying all the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
2 of 6 open independent living youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of an initial mutually agreed upon agreement between the youth and the agency.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2021 Interim inspection with the corrective
plan approved on 1/31/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
3 of 4 closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) and (d) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023.
9

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing,
counseling and mental health services, and
emergency resources.
(b) A birth certificate.
(c) A social security card.
(d) The youth's funds and personal property.
3 of 4 closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a)-(d) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12602 Program statement.
(3) An agency shall document that the statement was
provided to all persons making inquiry about the
agency's services.
1 of 2 denied adoptive family adoption records reviewed did not show
documentation of the program statement being provided to the family.
CPA Rule 400.12603 Policy and procedures
(2) An agency shall document that the policies and
procedures were provided to all persons making inquiry
about the agency's services.
1 of 2 denied adoptive family adoption records reviewed did not show
documentation that the agency policies and procedures were provided to the family.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided.
1 of 2 denied adoptive family adoption records reviewed did not show
documentation of an orientation for the family.
10

CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
1 of 4 adoptive family records reviewed did not show documentation that a copy of
the family's approved 4/11/2023 DHS-412 and DHS-5643 adoptive family
assessments were provided to the family upon its completion, as required by the
rule.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023.
ADM 300 Adoption Assessment and Addendum Assessment.
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment
Addendum, must be used to update the DHS-1927,
Child Adoption Assessment, on an annual basis if the
child has not been placed for adoption. The DHS-606,
Child Adoption Assessment Addendum must also be
completed when there is a change in placement or other
significant event for the child.
2 of 6 open foster child adoption records reviewed did not show documentation of
the child adoption assessment due by 10/15/2023 and 11/11/2023 respectively per
the child's 8/30/2023 and 9/27/2023 date of case acceptance.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2021 Interim inspection with the corrective
plan approved on 1/31/2022.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports.
When the child adoption assessment is used as the
initial quarterly report, the next quarterly report is due 90
calendar days from completion of the child adoption
assessment. When the child adoption assessment is not
completed within the initial required quarterly reporting
period, the DHS-614 is due 90 calendar days from case
11

acceptance or 90 days after the order terminating
parental rights is signed, whichever is later
2 of 14 quarterly progress reports reviewed (related to 2 of 6 open child adoption
records reviewed) did not show compliance:
• One child's record did not show documentation of an August 2023 quarterly
progress report.
• A second child's record showed the quarterly due by 7/24/2024 was
completed late on 9/3/2023.
ADM 980 Closing Documentation.
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the
foster care worker and the Department of Health and
Services (DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of
service cases for inclusion in the child’s permanent
record. The DHS-222, Adoption Closing Summary must
be used for this purpose
2 of 4 closed child adoption records reviewed showed the child’s DHS-222 closing
summary was not completed within 14 days of the respective child's 8/9/2023 and
9/26/2023 final order of adoption date.
FOM 722-6H Case Contacts
Contact with Children-General Requirements- Quality
Visits
A quality visit is defined as one in which the case
manager:
• Meet with each child individually, without the presence
of other individuals…
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for
infants under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental,
mental health, and other needs and takes appropriate
action or offers services in response to the identified
needs of each child.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan
for parenting time, visits with siblings and other
relatives, and the child's permanency plan, in a
developmentally appropriate way while allowing the
child to ask questions and express viewpoints
3 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
12

• One record did not show documentation of a private meeting with the youth
for several home visits. Nor did a documented 3/20/2023 home visit case
contact document details about the visit or whether a safety assessment
occurred. It only indicated a "home visit occurred".
• A second child's record did not show documentation of a private meeting with
the youth in the home for the November and December 2023 home visit
contacts.
• In a third child's record nearly all of the home visit contacts lacked
documentations of a quality visit, or that a private meeting occurred with the
child. Several case contacts only documented that the visit occurred.
FOM 722-6 B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms
must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) – within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Semi-annual transition meeting:
Beginning at age 14, semi-annual transition meetings
must occur once every 180-calendar day to discuss a
child’s permanency goal and identify supportive adults.
8 of 8 open foster child record reviewed (related to 31 service plans reviewed) did
not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of an FTM as required by the policy
for the child's 9/2/2022-12/1/2022, 2/28/2023-5/26/2023, and next two
updated service plans.
• A second record did not show documentation of an FTM as required by the
policy for the child's 7/7/203-10/4/2023 updated service plan.
13

• A third record did not show documentation of an FTM related to the child's
6/8/2023, 6/22/2023 or 7/21/2023 placement change. Nor documentation of a
DHS-1105 for a reported 10/15/2023 FTM.
• A fourth record did not show documentation of an FTM as required by policy
for the child's 9/3/2022-12/3/2023, 2/28/2023-5/24/2023 7/12/2023-8/12/2023
for the child’s 8/18/2023-11/13/2023 updated service plan. Additionally, this
record did not show documentation a DHS-1105 for FTMs reported to have
occurred on 2/24/2023 and 3/10/2023.
• A fifth record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child 's 2/1/2023-
5/1/2023; or 7/28/2023-10/20/2023 update service plan. The record showed
an FTM held was on 6/19/2023 which was too early with respect to the FTM
timeframe for the child's 5/2/2023-7/27/2023 service plan. Additionally, this
record showed the child's semi-annual transition meeting due in November
2023 was completed late on 12/28/2023.
• A sixth record did not show documentation of a FTM for the child's
3/22/2023-6/19/2023 updated service plan.
• A seventh and eighth record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for
FTMs reported for 3/31/2023 and 10/26/2023.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2021 Interim
inspection with the corrective plan approved on 1/31/2022.
FOM 722-8 D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker.
• Supervisor.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
17 of 31 services plans reviewed (related to 6 of 8 open foster child cases reviewed)
and 1 of 14 service plans reviewed (related to 1 of 6 open independent youth
records) did not show compliance:
14

Open foster child records:
• One child’s 9/3/2022-12/1/2022, 12/2/2022-2/27/2023 and 8/22/2023-
11/19/2023 treatments plan did not show documentation of the caregiver’s
signature. The child’s 9/3/2022-12/1/2022 treatment plan was not signed by
the worker and supervisor until 8/22/2023.
• A second child’s 1/10/2023-4/7/2023 treatment was not signed by the birth
parent until 6/9/2023.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of the child’s 7/7/2023-
8/5/2023, and 8/6/2023-11/3/2023 treatment plans signed by the caregiver.
Nor the child’s 8/6/2023-11/3/2023 treatment plan signed by the birth parent.
• A fourth child’s record did not show documentation of the child’s 1/28/2023-
4/27/2023 or 7/27/2023-10/24/2023 treatment plan signed by the caregiver
and birth parent. Nor documentation of the child’s 4/28/2023-7/26/2023
treatment plan signed by the birth parent.
• A fifth child’s record did not show documentation of the child’s 12/2/2022-
2/27/2023 or 2/28/2023- 5/21/2023 treatment plan with the caregiver’s
signature. Additionally, this record showed the birth father’s signature for the
child’s 9/3/2023- 12/1/2023 treatment plan did not occur until 7/28/2023; his
signature for 12/2/2022-2/27/2023 treatment plan did not occur until 6/9/2023
and his signature for the 7/12/2023-8/17/2023 treatment plan did not occur
10/11/2023. All after the 30-day time frame required by the standard.
• A sixth child’s record did not show documentation that the child’s 12/22/2022-
3/21/2023 or 3/22/2023-6/19/2023 treatment plan was signed by the
caregiver.
Open independent living youth records:
The independent youth record did not show documentation that the youth’s
3/12/2023-6/19/2023 treatment plan was signed by the youth.
Repeat Violation; Cited during the 2022 Renewal inspection, with the
corrective action plan approved on 1/27/2023; and during the 2021 Interim
inspection, cited under 722.8C, with the corrective plan approved on
1/31/2022.
FOM 801-C Medical passport.
Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following.
Updated Medical Passport
15

All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information.
3 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of an updated medical
passport after 1/6/2023 and before 11/10/2023, when one was generated.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of a medical passport
between 10/23/2022 and 8/4/2023.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of a March 2023 medical

apparatuses the agency was uncertain of the degree of progress on the renewal

staff training logs for season staff still employed with the agency, personnel

repeat citations in this Interim report, the agency was not successful with a

received 34 citations compared to 26 citations during its 2022 renewal inspection;
and the 30 citations it received during its 2021 Interim inspection. The quantity of
